14.description: The Use SRTP data protection extension.

15.caption: heartbeat
15.description: The Heartbeat extension.

16.caption: application_layer_protocol_negotiation
16.description: The Application-Layer Protocol Negotiation extension.

18.caption: signed_certificate_timestamp
18.description: The Signed Certificate Timestamp extension.

20.caption: server_certificate_type
20.description: The Server Certificate Type extension.

21.caption: padding
21.description: The Padding extension.

45.caption: psk_key_exchange_modes
45.description: The Pre-Shared Key Exchange Modes extension.

13.caption: signature_algorithms
13.description: The Signature Algorithms extension.

19.caption: client_certificate_type
19.description: The Client Certificate Type extension.

query_info.caption: Query Information
query_info.name: query_info
query_info.description: The query info object holds information related to data access within a datastore. To access, manipulate, delete, or retrieve data from a datastore, a query must be written using a specific syntax.

data.caption: Data
data.description: The data returned from the query execution.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The query name for a saved or scheduled query.

bytes.caption: Total Bytes
bytes.description: The size of the data returned from the query.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the query.

query_string.caption: Query String
query_string.description: A string representing the query code being run. For example: SELECT * FROM my_table

query_time.caption: Query Time
query_time.description: The time when the query was run.

query_time_dt.caption: Query Time
query_time_dt.description: The time when the query was run.

module.caption: Module
module.name: module
module.description: The Module object describes the load attributes of a module.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The module type.

base_address.caption: Base Address
base_address.description: The memory address where the module was loaded.

function_name.caption: Function Name
function_name.description: The entry-point function of the module. The system calls the entry-point function whenever a process or thread loads or unloads the module.

load_type.caption: Load Type
load_type.description: The load type, normalized to the caption of the load_type_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source. It describes how the module was loaded in memory.

load_type_id.caption: Load Type ID
load_type_id.description: The normalized identifier of the load type. It identifies how the module was loaded in memory.

3.caption: ShellCode
3.description: A raw module in process memory that is READWRITE_EXECUTE and had a thread started in its range.

1.caption: Standard
1.description: A normal module loaded by the normal windows loading mechanism i.e. LoadLibrary.

2.caption: Non Standard
2.description: A module loaded in a way avoidant of normal windows procedures. i.e. Bootstrapped Loading/Manual Dll Loading.

4.caption: Mapped
4.description: A memory mapped file, typically created with CreatefileMapping/MapViewOfFile.

5.caption: NonStandard Backed
5.description: A module loaded in a non standard way. However, GetModuleFileName succeeds on this allocation.

start_address.caption: Start Address
start_address.description: The start address of the execution.

cve.caption: CVE
cve.name: cve
cve.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) object represents publicly disclosed cybersecurity vulnerabilities defined in CVE Program catalog (CVE). There is one CVE Record for each vulnerability in the catalog.

type.caption: Vulnerability Type
type.description:
The vulnerability type as selected from a large dropdown menu during CVE refinement.

Most frequently used vulnerability types are: DoS, Code Execution, Overflow, Memory Corruption, Sql Injection, XSS, Directory Traversal, Http Response Splitting, Bypass something, Gain Information, Gain Privileges, CSRF, File Inclusion. For more information see Vulnerabilities By Type distributions.

title.caption: Title
title.description: A title or a brief phrase summarizing the CVE record.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product where the vulnerability was discovered.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: A brief description of the CVE Record.

uid.caption: CVE ID
uid.description: The Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures unique number assigned to a specific computer vulnerability. A CVE Identifier begins with 4 digits representing the year followed by a sequence of digits that acts as a unique identifier. For example: CVE-2021-12345.

references.caption: References
references.description: A list of reference URLs with additional information about the CVE Record.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.

cvss.caption: CVSS Score
cvss.description: The CVSS object details Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) scores from the advisory that are related to the vulnerability.

cwe.caption: CWE
cwe.description: The CWE object represents a weakness in a software system that can be exploited by a threat actor to perform an attack. The CWE object is based on the Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) catalog.

cwe_uid.caption: CWE UID
cwe_uid.description: The Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) unique identifier. For example: CWE-787.

deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

cwe_url.caption: CWE URL
cwe_url.description: Common Weakness Enumeration (CWE) definition URL. For example: https://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/787.html.

deprecated.message: Use the cwe object attributes instead.

epss.caption: EPSS
epss.description: The Exploit Prediction Scoring System (EPSS) object describes the estimated probability a vulnerability will be exploited. EPSS is a community-driven effort to combine descriptive information about vulnerabilities (CVEs) with evidence of actual exploitation in-the-wild. (EPSS).

modified_time.caption: Modified Time
modified_time.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The Record Creation Date identifies when the CVE ID was issued to a CVE Numbering Authority (CNA) or the CVE Record was published on the CVE List. Note that the Record Creation Date does not necessarily indicate when this vulnerability was discovered, shared with the affected vendor, publicly disclosed, or updated in CVE.

modified_time_dt.caption: Modified Time
modified_time_dt.description: The Record Modified Date identifies when the CVE record was last updated.

actor.caption: Actor
actor.name: actor
actor.description: The Actor object contains details about the user, role, or process that initiated or performed a specific activity.

process.caption: Process
process.description: The process that initiated the activity.

user.caption: User
user.description: The user that initiated the activity or the user context from which the activity was initiated.

session.caption: Session
session.description: The user session from which the activity was initiated.

authorizations.caption: Authorization Information
authorizations.description: Provides details about an authorization, such as authorization outcome, and any associated policies related to the activity/event.

idp.caption: Identity Provider
idp.description: This object describes details about the Identity Provider used.

invoked_by.caption: Invoked by
invoked_by.description: The name of the service that invoked the activity as described in the event.

logger.caption: Logger
logger.name: logger
logger.description: The Logger object represents the device and product where events are stored with times for receipt and transmission.  This may be at the source device where the event occurred, a remote scanning device, intermediate hops, or the ultimate destination.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the logging product instance.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the logging product.

device.caption: Device
device.description: The device where the events are logged.

product.caption: Product
product.description: The product logging the event.  This may be the event source product, a management server product, a scanning product, a SIEM, etc.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the logging product instance.

log_level.caption: Log Level
log_level.description: The audit level at which an event was generated.

log_name.caption: Log Name
log_name.description: The event log name. For example, syslog file name or Windows logging subsystem: Security.

log_provider.caption: Log Provider
log_provider.description: The logging provider or logging service that logged the event. For example, Microsoft-Windows-Security-Auditing.

log_version.caption: Log Version
log_version.description: The event log schema version that specifies the format of the original event. For example syslog version or Cisco Log Schema Version.

logged_time.caption: Logged Time
logged_time.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

transmit_time.caption: Transmission Time
transmit_time.description: The time when the event was transmitted from the logging device to it's next destination

logged_time_dt.caption: Logged Time
logged_time_dt.description:
The time when the logging system collected and logged the event.

This attribute is distinct from the event time in that event time typically contain the time extracted from the original event. Most of the time, these two times will be different.

transmit_time_dt.caption: Transmission Time
transmit_time_dt.description: The time when the event was transmitted from the logging device to it's next destination

digital_signature.caption: Digital Signature
digital_signature.name: digital_signature
digital_signature.description: The Digital Signature object contains information about the cryptographic mechanism used to verify the authenticity, integrity, and origin of the file or application.

digest.caption: Message Digest
digest.description: The message digest attribute contains the fixed length message hash representation and the corresponding hashing algorithm information.

certificate.caption: Certificate
certificate.description: The certificate object containing information about the digital certificate.

algorithm.caption: Algorithm
algorithm.description: The digital signature algorithm used to create the signature, normalized to the caption of 'algorithm_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

algorithm_id.caption: Algorithm ID
algorithm_id.description: The identifier of the normalized digital signature algorithm.

3.caption: ECDSA
3.description: Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The algorithm is not mapped. See the algorithm attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: DSA
1.description: Digital Signature Algorithm (DSA).

2.caption: RSA
2.description: Rivest-Shamir-Adleman (RSA) Algorithm.

created_time.caption: Created Time
created_time.description: The time when the digital signature was created.

developer_uid.caption: Developer UID
developer_uid.description: The developer ID on the certificate that signed the file.

created_time_dt.caption: Created Time
created_time_dt.description: The time when the digital signature was created.

kill_chain_phase.caption: Kill Chain Phase
kill_chain_phase.name: kill_chain_phase
kill_chain_phase.description: The Kill Chain Phase object represents a single phase of a cyber attack, including the initial reconnaissance and planning stages up to the final objective of the attacker. It provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack. See Cyber Kill Chain®.

phase_id.caption: Kill Chain Phase ID
phase_id.description: The cyber kill chain phase identifier.

3.caption: Delivery
3.description: The intruders will use various tactics, such as phishing, infected USB drives, etc.

6.caption: Command & Control
6.description: Malware opens a command channel to enable the intruders to remotely manipulate the victim's system.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The kill chain phase is not mapped. See the phase attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

0.caption: Unknown
0.description: The kill chain phase is unknown.

1.caption: Reconnaissance
1.description: The attackers pick a target and perform a detailed analysis, start collecting information (email addresses, conferences information, etc.) and evaluate the victim’s vulnerabilities to determine how to exploit them.

2.caption: Weaponization
2.description: The attackers develop a malware weapon and aim to exploit the discovered vulnerabilities.

4.caption: Exploitation
4.description: The intruders start leveraging vulnerabilities to executed code on the victim’s system.

5.caption: Installation
5.description: The intruders install malware on the victim’s system.

7.caption: Actions on Objectives
7.description: With hands-on keyboard access, intruders accomplish the mission’s goal.

network_connection_info.caption: Network Connection Information
network_connection_info.name: network_connection_info
network_connection_info.description: The Network Connection Information object describes characteristics of a network connection. Defined by D3FEND d3f:NetworkSession.

uid.caption: Connection UID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the connection.

session.caption: Session
session.description: The authenticated user or service session.

boundary.caption: Boundary
boundary.description:
The boundary of the connection, normalized to the caption of 'boundary_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary(same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

protocol_name.caption: Protocol Name
protocol_name.description: The TCP/IP protocol name in lowercase, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). See Protocol Numbers. For example: tcp or udp.

direction.caption: Direction
direction.description: The direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email, normalized to the caption of the direction_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

boundary_id.caption: Boundary ID
boundary_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the boundary of the connection.

For cloud connections, this translates to the traffic-boundary (same VPC, through IGW, etc.). For traditional networks, this is described as Local, Internal, or External.

3.caption: External
3.description: External network traffic between two endpoints on the Internet or outside the network.

6.caption: Virtual Private Gateway
6.description: Through a virtual private gateway

99.caption: Other
99.description: The boundary is not mapped. See the boundary attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Localhost
1.description: Local network traffic on the same endpoint.

2.caption: Internal
2.description: Internal network traffic between two endpoints inside network.

10.caption: Gateway VPC
10.description: Through a gateway VPC endpoint (Nitro-based instances only)

4.caption: Same VPC
4.description: Through another resource in the same VPC

5.caption: Internet/VPC Gateway
5.description: Through an Internet gateway or a gateway VPC endpoint

7.caption: Intra-region VPC
7.description: Through an intra-region VPC peering connection

8.caption: Inter-region VPC
8.description: Through an inter-region VPC peering connection

9.caption: Local Gateway
9.description: Through a local gateway

11.caption: Internet Gateway
11.description: Through an Internet gateway (Nitro-based instances only)

direction_id.caption: Direction ID
direction_id.description: The normalized identifier of the direction of the initiated connection, traffic, or email.

3.caption: Lateral
3.description: Lateral network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the inside network.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The direction is not mapped. See the direction attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Inbound
1.description: Inbound network connection. The connection was originated from the Internet or outside network, destined for services on the inside network.

2.caption: Outbound
2.description: Outbound network connection. The connection was originated from inside the network, destined for services on the Internet or outside network.

protocol_num.caption: Protocol Number
protocol_num.description: The TCP/IP protocol number, as defined by the Internet Assigned Numbers Authority (IANA). Use -1 if the protocol is not defined by IANA. See Protocol Numbers. For example: 6 for TCP and 17 for UDP.

tcp_flags.caption: TCP Flags
tcp_flags.description: The network connection TCP header flags (i.e., control bits).

technique.caption: Technique
technique.name: technique
technique.description: The Technique object describes the technique ID and/or name associated to an attack, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: Active Scanning.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: T1595.

src_url.caption: Source URL
src_url.description: The versioned permalink of the attack technique, as defined by ATT&CK MatrixTM. For example: https://attack.mitre.org/versions/v14/techniques/T1595/.

firewall_rule.caption: Firewall Rule
firewall_rule.name: firewall_rule
firewall_rule.description: The Firewall Rule object represents a specific rule within a firewall policy or event. It contains information about a rule's configuration, properties, and associated actions that define how network traffic is handled by the firewall.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the rule that generated the event.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The rule type.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the rule that generated the event.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the rule that generated the event.

duration.caption: Duration
duration.description: The rule response time duration, usually used for challenge completion time.

condition.caption: Condition
condition.description: The rule trigger condition for the rule. For example: SQL_INJECTION.

sensitivity.caption: Sensitivity
sensitivity.description: The sensitivity of the firewall rule in the matched event. For example: HIGH.

match_location.caption: Match Location
match_location.description: The location of the matched data in the source which resulted in the triggered firewall rule. For example: HEADER.

match_details.caption: Match Details
match_details.description: The data in a request that rule matched. For example: '["10","and","1"]'.

rate_limit.caption: Rate Limit
rate_limit.description: The rate limit for a rate-based rule.

account.caption: Account
account.name: account
account.description: The Account object contains details about the account that initiated or performed a specific activity within a system or application.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the account (e.g. GCP Account Name).

type.caption: Type
type.description: The account type, normalized to the caption of 'account_type_id'. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the account (e.g. AWS Account ID).

99.caption: Other
99.description: The account type is not mapped.

scan.caption: Scan
scan.name: scan
scan.description: The Scan object describes characteristics of a proactive scan.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The administrator-supplied or application-generated name of the scan. For example: "Home office weekly user database scan", "Scan folders for viruses", "Full system virus scan"

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of scan.

uid.caption: Scan UID
uid.description: The application-defined unique identifier assigned to an instance of a scan.

type_id.caption: Type ID
type_id.description: The type id of the scan.

3.caption: Updated Content
3.description: The scan was triggered by a content update.

6.caption: User Logon
6.description: The scan was started due to a user logon.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The scan type id is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Manual
1.description: The scan was manually initiated by the user or administrator.

2.caption: Scheduled
2.description: The scan was started based on scheduler.

4.caption: Quarantined Items
4.description: The scan was triggered by newly quarantined items.

5.caption: Attached Media
5.description: The scan was triggered by the attachment of removable media.

7.caption: ELAM
7.description: The scan was triggered by an Early Launch Anti-Malware (ELAM) detection.

network_endpoint.caption: Network Endpoint
network_endpoint.name: network_endpoint
network_endpoint.description: The Network Endpoint object describes characteristics of a network endpoint. These can be a source or destination of a network connection.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The short name of the endpoint.

port.caption: Port
port.description: The port used for communication within the network connection.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The network endpoint type. For example: unknown, server, desktop, laptop, tablet, mobile, virtual, browser, or other.

ip.caption: IP Address
ip.description: The IP address of the endpoint, in either IPv4 or IPv6 format.

location.caption: Geo Location
location.description: The geographical location of the endpoint.

hostname.caption: Hostname
hostname.description: The fully qualified name of the endpoint.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the endpoint.

mac.caption: MAC Address
mac.description: The Media Access Control (MAC) address of the endpoint.

3.caption: Laptop
3.description: A laptop computer.

6.caption: Virtual
6.description: A virtual machine.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Server
1.description: A server.

2.caption: Desktop
2.description: A desktop computer.

10.caption: Switch
10.description: A networking switch.

5.caption: Mobile
5.description: A mobile phone.

7.caption: IOT
7.description: A IOT (Internet of Things) device.

8.caption: Browser
8.description: A web browser.

9.caption: Firewall
9.description: A networking firewall.

11.caption: Hub
11.description: A networking hub.

container.caption: Container
container.description: The information describing an instance of a container. A container is a prepackaged, portable system image that runs isolated on an existing system using a container runtime like containerd.

instance_uid.caption: Instance ID
instance_uid.description: The unique identifier of a VM instance.

interface_name.caption: Network Interface Name
interface_name.description: The name of the network interface (e.g. eth2).

interface_uid.caption: Network Interface ID
interface_uid.description: The unique identifier of the network interface.

intermediate_ips.caption: Intermediate IP Addresses
intermediate_ips.description: The intermediate IP Addresses. For example, the IP addresses in the HTTP X-Forwarded-For header.

namespace_pid.caption: Namespace PID
namespace_pid.description: If running under a process namespace (such as in a container), the process identifier within that process namespace.

proxy_endpoint.caption: Proxy Endpoint
proxy_endpoint.description: The network proxy information pertaining to a specific endpoint. This can be used to describe information pertaining to network address translation (NAT).

subnet_uid.caption: Subnet UID
subnet_uid.description: The unique identifier of a virtual subnet.

svc_name.caption: Service Name
svc_name.description: The service name in service-to-service connections. For example, AWS VPC logs the pkt-src-aws-service and pkt-dst-aws-service fields identify the connection is coming from or going to an AWS service.

vpc_uid.caption: VPC UID
vpc_uid.description: The unique identifier of the Virtual Private Cloud (VPC).

zone.caption: Network Zone
zone.description: The network zone or LAN segment.

related_event.caption: Related Event
related_event.name: related_event
related_event.description: The Related Event object describes an event related to a finding or detection as identified by the security product.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The type of the related event. For example: Process Activity: Launch.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the related event.

type_uid.caption: Type ID
type_uid.description: The unique identifier of the related event type. For example: 100701.

observables.caption: Observables
observables.description: The observables associated with the event or a finding.

attacks.caption: MITRE ATT&CK® Details
attacks.description: An array of MITRE ATT&CK® objects describing the tactics, techniques & sub-techniques identified by a security control or finding.

kill_chain.caption: Kill Chain
kill_chain.description: The Cyber Kill Chain® provides a detailed description of each phase and its associated activities within the broader context of a cyber attack.

product_uid.caption: Product Identifier
product_uid.description: The unique identifier of the product that reported the related event.

cloud.caption: Cloud
cloud.name: cloud
cloud.description: The Cloud object contains information about a cloud account such as AWS Account ID, regions, etc.

org.caption: Organization
org.description: Organization and org unit relevant to the event or object.

account.caption: Account
account.description: The account object describes details about the account that was the source or target of the activity.

project_uid.caption: Project ID
project_uid.description: The unique identifier of a Cloud project.

provider.caption: Provider
provider.description: The unique name of the Cloud services provider, such as AWS, MS Azure, GCP, etc.

region.caption: Region
region.description: The name of the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

zone.caption: Network Zone
zone.description: The availability zone in the cloud region, as defined by the cloud provider.

policy.caption: Policy
policy.name: policy
policy.description:
The Policy object describes the policies that are applicable.

Policy attributes provide traceability to the operational state of the security product at the time that the event was captured, facilitating forensics, troubleshooting, and policy tuning/adjustments.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The policy name. For example: IAM Policy.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the policy.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: A unique identifier of the policy instance.

rule.caption: Rule
rule.name: rule
rule.description: The Rule object describes characteristics of a rule associated with a policy or an event.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the rule that generated the event.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The rule type.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the rule that generated the event.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the rule that generated the event.

analytic.caption: Analytic
analytic.name: analytic
analytic.description: The Analytic object contains details about the analytic technique used to analyze and derive insights from the data or information that led to the creation of a finding or conclusion.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the analytic that generated the finding.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The analytic type.

desc.caption: Description
desc.description: The description of the analytic that generated the finding.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the analytic that generated the finding.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The type is not mapped. See the type attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

related_analytics.caption: Related Analytics
related_analytics.description: Other analytics related to this analytic.

deprecated.message: Related Analytics has been decoupled from this object, instead use finding_info.related_analytics.

resource_details.caption: Resource Details
resource_details.name: resource_details
resource_details.description: The Resource Details object describes details about resources that were affected by the activity/event.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the resource.

owner.caption: Owner
owner.description: The identity of the service or user account that owns the resource.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The resource type as defined by the event source.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the resource. For example 1.2.3.

group.caption: Group
group.description: The name of the related resource group.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The unique identifier of the resource.

labels.caption: Labels
labels.description: The list of labels/tags associated to a resource.

namespace.caption: Namespace
namespace.description: The namespace is useful when similar entities exist that you need to keep separate.

cloud_partition.caption: Cloud Partition
cloud_partition.description: The canonical cloud partition name to which the region is assigned (e.g. AWS Partitions: aws, aws-cn, aws-us-gov).

criticality.caption: Criticality
criticality.description: The criticality of the resource as defined by the event source.

region.caption: Region
region.description: The cloud region of the resource.

managed_entity.caption: Managed Entity
managed_entity.name: managed_entity
managed_entity.description: The Managed Entity object describes the type and version of an entity, such as a policy or configuration.

data.caption: Data
data.description: The managed entity content as a JSON object.

name.caption: Name
name.description: The name of the managed entity.

type.caption: Type
type.description: The managed entity type. For example: policy, user, organizational unit, device.

version.caption: Version
version.description: The version of the managed entity. For example: 1.2.3.

uid.caption: Unique ID
uid.description: The identifier of the managed entity.

datetime_t.caption: Datetime
datetime_t.description: The Internet Date/Time format as defined in RFC-3339. For example 1985-04-12T23:20:50.52Z.

file_hash_t.caption: Hash
file_hash_t.description: Hash. A unique value that corresponds to the content of the file, image, ja3_hash or hassh found in the schema. For example MD5: 3172ac7e2b55cbb81f04a6e65855a628.

hostname_t.caption: Hostname
hostname_t.description: Unique name assigned to a device connected to a computer network. A domain name in general is an Internet address that can be resolved through the Domain Name System (DNS). For example: r2-d2.example.com.

ip_t.caption: IP Address
ip_t.description: Internet Protocol address (IP address), in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. For example, 192.168.200.24 or 2001:0db8:85a3:0000:0000:8a2e:0370:7334.

json_t.caption: JSON
json_t.description: Embedded JSON value. A value can be a string, or a number, or true or false or null, or an object or an array. These structures can be nested. See www.json.org.

mac_t.caption: MAC Address
mac_t.description: Media Access Control (MAC) address. For example: 18:36:F3:98:4F:9A.

port_t.caption: Port
port_t.description: The TCP/UDP port number. For example: 80 or 22.

resource_uid_t.caption: Resource UID
resource_uid_t.description: Resource unique identifier. For example, S3 Bucket name or EC2 Instance ID.

subnet_t.caption: Subnet
subnet_t.description:
The subnet represented in a CIDR notation, using the format network_address/prefix_length. The network_address can be in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. The prefix length indicates the number of bits used for the network portion, and the remaining bits are available for host addresses within that subnet.
For example:
  • 192.168.1.0/24
  • 2001:0db8:85a3:0000::/64

timestamp_t.caption: Timestamp
timestamp_t.description: The timestamp format is the number of milliseconds since the Epoch 01/01/1970 00:00:00 UTC. For example 1618524549901.

url_t.caption: URL String
url_t.description: Uniform Resource Locator (URL) string. For example: http://www.example.com/download/trouble.exe.

base_event.caption: Base Event
base_event.name: base_event

count.caption: Count
count.description: The number of times that events in the same logical group occurred during the event Start Time to End Time period.

message.caption: Message
message.description: The description of the event/finding, as defined by the source.

status.caption: Status
status.description: The event status, normalized to the caption of the status_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the event source.

time.caption: Event Time
time.description: The normalized event occurrence time or the finding creation time.

metadata.caption: Metadata
metadata.description: The metadata associated with the event or a finding.

start_time.caption: Start Time
start_time.description: The start time of a time period, or the time of the least recent event included in the aggregate event.

severity.caption: Severity
severity.description: The event/finding severity, normalized to the caption of the severity_id value. In the case of 'Other', it is defined by the source.

duration.caption: Duration
duration.description: The event duration or aggregate time, the amount of time the event covers from start_time to end_time in milliseconds.

type_name.caption: Type Name
type_name.description: The event/finding type name, as defined by the type_uid.

activity_id.caption: Activity ID
activity_id.description: The normalized identifier of the activity that triggered the event.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event activity is not mapped. See the activity_name attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

type_uid.caption: Type ID
type_uid.description: The event/finding type ID. It identifies the event's semantics and structure. The value is calculated by the logging system as: class_uid * 100 + activity_id.

observables.caption: Observables
observables.description: The observables associated with the event or a finding.

category_name.caption: Category
category_name.description: The event category name, as defined by category_uid value.

class_uid.caption: Class ID
class_uid.description: The unique identifier of a class. A Class describes the attributes available in an event.

0.caption: Base Event
0.description: The base event is a generic and concrete event. It also defines a set of attributes available in most event classes. As a generic event that does not belong to any event category, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the schema.

category_uid.caption: Category ID
category_uid.description: The category unique identifier of the event.

class_name.caption: Class
class_name.description: The event class name, as defined by class_uid value: Base Event.

timezone_offset.caption: Timezone Offset
timezone_offset.description: The number of minutes that the reported event time is ahead or behind UTC, in the range -1,080 to +1,080.

raw_data.caption: Raw Data
raw_data.description: The raw event/finding data as received from the source.

unmapped.caption: Unmapped Data
unmapped.description: The attributes that are not mapped to the event schema. The names and values of those attributes are specific to the event source.

activity_name.caption: Activity
activity_name.description: The event activity name, as defined by the activity_id.

end_time.caption: End Time
end_time.description: The end time of a time period, or the time of the most recent event included in the aggregate event.

enrichments.caption: Enrichments
enrichments.description:
The additional information from an external data source, which is associated with the event or a finding. For example add location information for the IP address in the DNS answers:

[{"name": "answers.ip", "value": "92.24.47.250", "type": "location", "data": {"city": "Socotra", "continent": "Asia", "coordinates": [-25.4153, 17.0743], "country": "YE", "desc": "Yemen"}}]

severity_id.caption: Severity ID
severity_id.description:
The normalized identifier of the event/finding severity.

The normalized severity is a measurement the effort and expense required to manage and resolve an event or incident. Smaller numerical values represent lower impact events, and larger numerical values represent higher impact events.

3.caption: Medium
3.description: Action is required but the situation is not serious at this time.

6.caption: Fatal
6.description: An error occurred but it is too late to take remedial action.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event/finding severity is not mapped. See the severity attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

1.caption: Informational
1.description: Informational message. No action required.

2.caption: Low
2.description: The user decides if action is needed.

5.caption: Critical
5.description: Action is required immediately and the scope is broad.

status_code.caption: Status Code
status_code.description:
The event status code, as reported by the event source.

For example, in a Windows Failed Authentication event, this would be the value of 'Failure Code', e.g. 0x18.

status_detail.caption: Status Details
status_detail.description: The status details contains additional information about the event/finding outcome.

status_id.caption: Status ID
status_id.description: The normalized identifier of the event status.

99.caption: Other
99.description: The event status is not mapped. See the status attribute, which contains a data source specific value.

base_event.description: The base event is a generic and concrete event. It also defines a set of attributes available in most event classes. As a generic event that does not belong to any event category, it could be used to log events that are not otherwise defined by the schema.
